It mentions that Walcott, along with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. The article notes the irony that Walcott has been "on a different kind of bench" for this photoshoot while having spent much of the actual season on the substitutes' bench (17 of 33 Premier League games). The passage concludes by noting that Walcott played only six minutes in Arsenal's recent draw with Chelsea and hopes to make his first start since March 14 in an upcoming match against Hull.

# Rick Baker's Hollywood Props and Puppets Auction

A remarkable collection of 417 props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection from Baker's Cinovation Studio spans his 30-year career and is estimated to be worth $746,100.

The auction features items from more than 50 productions, including blockbusters like Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Gremlins 2, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker. Notable pieces include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black (estimated at $40,000), the Mikey costume ($30,000), the Grinch costume ($8,000), and the iconic Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000).

This no-reserve auction will give fans and collectors their first opportunity to own pieces of Hollywood history created by the 64-year-old Baker, whose work also included An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and Hellboy.

# Summary of Passage

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died in a tragic skiing accident in the French Alps when he became separated from his family during their final run of the day. After his sister lost her ski and his mother stopped to help, Carwyn continued ahead but left the piste and entered woodland, apparently trying to reach the resort he could see through the trees. Police followed his footprints in the snow, which led to where he had fallen over a 164-foot drop. 

The family described Carwyn, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, as a "daring, outgoing and determined" child who had been skiing since age three and was a "very competent skier." In their tribute, they said his death left "a vast void in their hearts" and that "seven years is too short a time to be an angel in the sky." The local community, including his school where a condolence book has been placed, is mourning his loss.

# Summary of Laura Scurr's Battle with Anorexia

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 after feeling pressured to achieve a "size zero" figure. Her condition became life-threatening as she restricted herself to as little as 100 calories per day, sometimes consuming just a single piece of fruit. She would hide food, lie about eating, and use tactics like placing food under mashed potatoes to deceive her parents.

Laura's severe malnutrition eventually caused her body to begin shutting down. After collapsing at home, she was hospitalized and placed on a heart monitor for a week. Her dangerous weight loss was initially triggered by bullying about her weight and observations of peers and media promoting thinness.

Following her hospitalization, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery journey. Now healthier with improved body image, she has reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive experiences for young girls away from size zero stereotypes.

# Liverpool Unveils New Balance Home Kit Amid Sterling Contract Speculation

The article describes Liverpool FC's unveiling of their 2015/16 home kit, the first from New Balance following a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal. Players Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet presented the new kit to fans at Anfield.

Special attention focused on Sterling, who had recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and gave an interview expressing his flattery at being linked with Arsenal. During the event, a fan called out "make sure we see you in that next season," which was met with applause from other supporters. Despite speculation about his future, Liverpool maintains the 20-year-old will not be leaving this summer.

The players also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with Sterling noting it was special to play in his hometown and Sturridge expressing that winning the FA Cup would be significant for everyone associated with the club.

The new kit features all-white branding, a new collar style, and includes the memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims.

# Summary of Dark Matter Mapping

Scientists from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, have produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter. This map, created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, currently shows dark matter distribution across 0.4% of the sky (approximately 150 times the area of the full moon).

The map is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to eventually map 12.5% of the sky, creating a comprehensive 3D view of dark matter and dark energy distribution. Though dark matter cannot be directly observed because it doesn't interact with light, researchers can detect it through gravitational lensing—studying how it bends light around distant galaxies.

The team analyzed 130 million telescope images using supercomputers to create the map. Their findings show large filaments of matter along which visible galaxies are located, supporting theories that galaxies form in areas with higher concentrations of dark matter. Understanding how dark matter clumping changes over time will help reveal the nature of dark energy, which is the ultimate goal of the survey.

# Manchester United Makes Official Approach for PSV's Memphis Depay

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, as confirmed by the Dutch club's technical director. United manager Louis van Gaal, who worked with Depay during the 2014 World Cup where Holland finished third, is keen to make him one of his first summer signings.

PSV has also received interest from Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club, with the technical director indicating Depay is now worth significantly more than the £15 million Tottenham offered last summer.

Depay is having an exceptional season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Known for his pace, dribbling ability, and powerful right foot, Depay typically plays on the left wing. His potential has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben, with one former Manchester United scout suggesting he's better than Cristiano Ronaldo was at the same age.

# Youth Cup Match Summary: Chelsea Takes 3-1 Lead Over Manchester City

Chelsea has secured a commanding 3-1 advantage in the first leg of the Youth Cup tie against Manchester City at the Academy Stadium in Manchester. 

Tammy Abraham was the standout performer, netting twice in the first half to reach 36 goals for the season before being substituted with a potential injury in the 67th minute. Dominic Solanke added a third goal late in the match to extend Chelsea's lead.

Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly leveled the score in the first half, but the home side couldn't contain Chelsea's attack. Brandon Barker was City's most threatening player, while Chelsea dominated the midfield battle through captain Charlie Colkett and Ruben Sammut, who effectively protected their back four.

The strong performance gives Chelsea a significant advantage as they return to West London for the second leg.

# Summary of Marco Rubio's Stance on Gay Marriage

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, has stated that while he believes people are "born with a sexual preference," he does not consider same-sex marriage a constitutional right. Rubio maintains that marriage should be defined as "between one man and one woman" and that states, not courts, should regulate marriage through their legislatures.

Despite his personal views, Rubio said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, explaining he wouldn't "hurt them simply because I disagree with a choice they've made." He compared this to his Catholic view on divorce, saying he believes divorce is wrong but wouldn't stop loving someone who got divorced.

The passage also notes that Rubio recently announced his presidential run and has reportedly secured significant campaign funding.

# Cycle Journey Around the World: Pablo and Ilze's Adventure

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are a couple who quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world with no specific plans or agenda. After nearly a year on the road, they've covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries while living on an extremely tight budget of less than 3 euros per person daily.

The couple keeps costs low by primarily camping (161 of 256 nights) and using free accommodation services like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their only major expense is food at 2.74 euros per day, consisting mainly of basic items like pasta, bread, rice, eggs, and seasonal produce.

Their journey began in London and has taken them through Western Europe, the Balkans, and into Asia. After traversing Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, they plan to continue through Asia, cross the Pacific, and eventually cycle the length of the Americas. They expect their open-ended adventure to continue for "the following years."

# Summary of Texas Wedding Photo Booth Controversy

A Texas couple who married in 2012 is suing photographer James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth pictures at their wedding. The couple only discovered the offensive prints months after their wedding when the bride's sister revealed the issue, having kept quiet initially to avoid ruining the celebration.

When confronted, Evans reportedly told the couple to "sue me" without offering an apology. The couple has filed a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied all allegations, stating there's no evidence connecting his company to the offensive captions at an event with 103 attendees.

According to the couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, they primarily want an apology. If mediation fails, the case is set for trial in July.

# Summary: Mike Brown Taking Cautious Approach to Concussion Recovery

England full-back Mike Brown is unsure when he will return to action after experiencing concussion symptoms following a match against France. Brown pulled out of Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley as a precautionary measure. This follows a previous concussion during England's Six Nations victory over Italy in February, when he was knocked unconscious.

Brown emphasizes the importance of a cautious approach to avoid prolonged absence from the sport, citing examples of other players like George North (advised not to play again this season after four concussions) and Johnny Sexton (stood down for 12 weeks). 

He credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms through World Rugby's online modules for helping him make responsible decisions about his health. Brown is taking a stage-by-stage approach to recovery and advocates for players to be honest about symptoms rather than risking further injury, stating "It's just not worth pushing through."

# Declining Sexual Frequency Linked to Smartphone Use

Research indicates that the frequency of sexual activity among British couples has been declining since the emergence of the internet. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University, typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times monthly, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. 

The decrease may be attributed to technology blurring the boundaries between public and private life. With people constantly checking emails and lacking "quiet empty time," intimacy has been pushed aside. Other factors include more people living alone and increased work-life integration.

Researcher Catherine Mercer suggests that with competing demands on time, sex has fallen down the priority list, and evening technology use means people remain "too connected" to focus on their partners by bedtime.

# Summary of Tibetan Mastiffs' Fall from Grace in China

Tibetan mastiffs, large dogs weighing up to 80kg that were traditionally used as herding animals in Tibet, have experienced a dramatic reversal of fortune in China. Just a year ago, these dogs commanded prices up to £1.2 million each as status symbols, with one puppy selling for what's believed to be the highest price ever paid for a dog.

Today, these once-prized animals are being sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots and their skin for leather products. This decline is attributed to several factors:

1. The Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown has eliminated the practice of giving mastiffs as expensive gifts to influence officials.

2. Several major Chinese cities have banned owning dogs over 50kg.

3. Profit-driven cross-breeding has deteriorated the breed's appearance and temperament.

4. Increasing urbanization has made people realize these large dogs aren't suitable for city living.

Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs being transported to a slaughterhouse in cruel conditions, with a third already dead and others suffering from injuries and neglect. This case highlights what animal charities fear is happening to hundreds of mastiffs across China.

# Summary: Sexual Harassment on Paris Public Transport

A survey of 600 women in Paris found that every respondent reported experiencing sexual harassment on public transportation, with half first experiencing harassment before age 18. The harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behavior to sexual attacks or rape. This widespread issue causes 60% of women to fear being attacked on public transport compared to 30% of men, forcing many women to alter their daily routines, routes, and behaviors to avoid confrontation.

The High Council for Gender Equality, which compiled the report for the French women's rights ministry, noted that these incidents often go unreported, effectively excluding women from public spaces. Officials expressed surprise at the pervasiveness of the problem and called for educational campaigns targeting potential harassers, victims, and witnesses, emphasizing that such behavior carries serious legal penalties.

# Summary: Everyday Emergency Solutions Competition

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, is running an #everydayfix competition featuring prototype products designed to solve common everyday problems. After surveying 2,000 people to identify the top "everyday emergencies," London-based design company Makerversity created solutions for these issues.

Three products were shortlisted:
1. **Snooze** - An alarm clock that connects to phones and silences notifications to address sleep problems (the top concern for 46% of respondents)
2. **Forget Me Lock** - A key attachment that shows green when a door is open and red when locked
3. **Nipper** - Described as the world's smallest mobile phone charger, using household batteries

The public can vote for their favorite by retweeting on Twitter with the #everydayfix hashtag. The winning product will be funded through Kickstarter and developed into an actual product.

Other product concepts that didn't make the final cut included a smart cycling helmet with navigation, a parking space alert system, and an app that forwards messages when your phone dies.

# Summary of Assault Case in Philadelphia

Five individuals were involved in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man named Greg Valecce in Philadelphia. Two others are still awaiting sentencing or trial. The court heard that despite having the offensive tattoos removed, Valecce continues to suffer psychological trauma from the incident.

# Summary of Marco Rubio's Stance on Gay Marriage

In an interview with CBS's Face the Nation, presidential candidate Marco Rubio expressed his belief that people are born with their sexual preference while maintaining that same-sex marriage should not be considered a constitutional right. The Florida senator stated that marriage should be "between one man and one woman" and argued that marriage regulations should be determined by state legislatures rather than courts. Despite his personal views, Rubio indicated he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, saying, "You respect that because you love them." Rubio recently announced his presidential campaign, with donors reportedly committing over $47 million to support his primary run.

# World Cyclists Living on €3 a Day: Pablo and Ilze's No-Agenda Adventure

Spanish Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian Ilze Zebolde (31) are cycling around the world with no plans or agenda, simply wanting to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they've spent 356 days traveling almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries across Europe and into Asia.

The couple lives remarkably frugally, spending just €2.99 each per day (€0.10 per kilometer). They minimize costs by camping (161 of 256 nights) and using free accommodation services like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights). Their diet consists mainly of basic staples, occasionally supplemented by donations or foraged food.

Starting in London, they've traversed western and eastern Europe, symbolically crossing into Asia via Turkey. They've continued through Georgia and Armenia, with plans to journey across Asia, cross the Pacific, and cycle the length of the Americas in the coming years.

# Summary: Mike Brown's Cautious Approach to Concussion Recovery

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovery after experiencing concussion symptoms following a France game, though he remains uncertain about his return timeline. Brown, who was previously knocked out during England's Six Nations match against Italy in February, pulled out of Harlequins' clash with Saracens due to ongoing headaches. He emphasizes the importance of careful recovery to avoid extended absences like those experienced by Johnny Sexton and George North, the latter having suffered four quick-fire concussions and being advised not to play again this season.

Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, partly through World Rugby's online educational modules, for helping him make responsible decisions about his health. He advocates strongly for player safety, stating that if he could withdraw from a crucial England-Ireland Six Nations match, other players should likewise prioritize their health over competition, concluding "it's just not worth pushing through."

# Decline in Sexual Activity Linked to Technology Use

Research reveals that British couples are having sex less frequently since the emergence of the internet. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University, heterosexual couples now have sex approximately three times monthly, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990.

The declining frequency may be attributed to smartphone use and increased connectivity, which have blurred boundaries between public and private life. People constantly checking emails and handling work matters in the evening leaves less dedicated time for intimate relationships.

As Catherine Mercer, a British National Survey researcher, notes, sex is becoming lower priority due to competing demands on people's time, with late-night digital connectivity making it difficult for couples to focus exclusively on their partners.

# Tibetan Mastiffs: From Luxury Status Symbol to Slaughterhouse

This passage describes the dramatic fall of Tibetan Mastiffs in China's pet market. Once commanding prices up to £1.2 million as status symbols, these large dogs (weighing up to 80kg) are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather.

The decline is attributed to several factors:
- China's anti-corruption campaign preventing their use as gifts to officials
- City bans on dogs over 50kg
- Poor breeding practices diminishing their quality
- Urbanization making people realize they're unsuitable for city living

Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs in cramped cages heading to a slaughterhouse, with many dead or injured. Across China, these once-prized dogs are being stolen from streets or sold by breeders who can't sell their stock. This represents a dramatic reversal from just 13 months ago when one puppy sold for a record £1.2 million.

# Everyday Fix Competition for Common Problems

This article describes a competition called #everydayfix run by Leeds-based Direct Line to address common "everyday emergencies" that cause stress in people's lives. After surveying 2,000 people about their daily frustrations, London-based design company Makerversity created prototype solutions for these problems.

Three finalist products were selected:

1. **Snooze** - An alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications to ensure better sleep (addressing the top concern of 46% of respondents)

2. **Forget Me Lock** - A key attachment that shows green when a door is open and red when locked, helping people remember if they secured their home

3. **Nipper** - Described as the world's smallest mobile phone charger, using household batteries as an emergency power source

The public can vote for their favorite by retweeting on Twitter with the #everydayfix hashtag. The winning prototype will receive Kickstarter funding for development into an actual product.

Other prototypes that didn't make the final shortlist included a smart cycling helmet with navigation, a parking space alert system, and an app that forwards messages when your phone dies.
